prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: GRB030329
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
We aim to locate star-forming regions within GRBHs and study their dust content. We opt for the best resolution achievable with the standard configuration (0.14'' in band 7), suitable for testing the existence of bright dusty star-forming regions <1 kpc from the GRB position (See Tab 1 in the science case).
The redshifts of our targets allow us to simultaneously pinpoint the CO(3-2) or CO(4-3) emission lines (345.796 and 461.041 GHz) in band 7. However, we note that detecting this line is not the main aim of this proposal.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
RMS: The expected total flux is 1 mJy, and we want to detect the star-forming regions close to GRB positions if they contribute 20% of the total flux (as for GRB 980425), so we require 0.05 mJy RMS to obtain a 4 sigma detection.
Time: This corresponds to ~40 min of time per source (depending on the declination) and a total ~3.1 hr for 4 sources including calibration. This was calculated with the OT assuming an average weather condition of precipitable water vapour of 0.658 - 1.262 mm (2nd - 4th octile, depending on declination).
Additional goal: For the spectral window with the CO line this will result in the rms of ~1.6 mJy per ~8 km/s channels, so we will be able to detect the line if the star-forming region is similar to the WR region in the GRB 980425 host (peak flux of 15 mJy), based on our ALMA data for that object (Michalowski et al., in prep).
Special constraints on standard observing modes: The proposed targets are GRB hosts, which are spread uniformly on the sky, so in all cases it was not possible to find any other suitable target within <10 deg. This results in significant overheads, but this is the only way to observe these unique extragalactic objects, which were not selected from deep fields (similarly to high-z quasars).
calibration: default
Bandpass accuracy: Standard
Scheduling/time constraints: None
Data rate: Normal

We have chosen the band 7 as it gives the best infrared luminosity limit for a given integration time compared to other bands. It still probes the dust emission (unlike lower frequency bands), but is not so weather dependant as band 8 and 9. As an additional goal of the proposal we tuned one spectral window to the frequency of the CO(3-2) or CO(4-3) line.
In order to achieve the best possible sensitivity we will use the dual polarisation mode. We selected the Frequency Division Mode for the spectral window tracing the CO line. This will result in the spectral resolution of ~ 1 km/s, so we bin the spectrum to obtain a significant signal, as the expected line width is of the order of a few tens km/s. However, we note that detecting this line is not the main aim of this proposal. For other spectral windows we selected the Time Division Mode to limit the data rate.

Our goal is to test whether dusty star-forming regions are located close (<1kpc) to the GRB position (as for GRB 980425). Therefore we request the spatial resolution of 0.14'', which corresponds to 0.1-0.7 kpc for our targets (Tab 1). This is achievable with the C36-5 configuration, the most extended one among the standard configurations. The regions will be point sources at this resolution, so the consideration of the maximum resolvable scale is not necessary for our science goals. We do not aim at detecting the overall smooth emission of the entire target galaxies, hence we do not ask for ACA observations.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Long gamma-ray bursts (LGRBs) are bright explosions signaling the death of short-lived massive stars, but the properties of the environment that foster the birth of a LGRB progenitor are still under debate. We propose to use the unrivaled resolution and sensitivity of ALMA in Band 7 to localize star-forming regions in 4 LGRB host galaxies to constrain their dust mass and morphology. Our observations will help to understand whether LGRBs are born in particular dense regions, and if the standard collapsar scenario is the best hypothesis. The results will have strong implications on whether LGRBs are good tracers of star formation over cosmic time.
